section.title: Area and Arc Length in Polar Coordinates

li.p: How can we compute the area of a sector bounded by a curve?
How can we find the area between two curves?
How can we compute slope and arc length in polar coordinates?

introduction.p: Any point P = (x,y) on the Cartesian plane can be represented in polar coordinates using its distance from the origin point (0,0) and the angle formed from the positive x-axis counterclockwise to the point. Sometimes this representation provides a more useful way of describing the point's location, or all of the points along a curve, than conventional Cartesian coordinates.

Representing curves in polar coordinates, we can ask the same questions such as What is the area under the curve? and How long is the curve? . In this section we learn how the definite integral may be used to find answers to these questions.

statement.p: Find the polar coordinates of a point with the Cartesian coordinates (x,y)=(3,-4)

solution.p: Let's start by plotting the point (x,y)=(3,-4) on a graph and using the Pythagorean theorem to find the corresponding radius of the point. We get that

Now that we know the radius, we can find the angle using any of the three trigonometric relationships. Keep in mind that there may be more than one solution when solving for \theta and we will need to consider the quadrant that our (x,y) point is in to decide which solution to use.

Using the cosine function, we get that \cos(\theta) = \frac{x}{r} = \frac{3}{5} = 0.6 Since this cosine value does not correspond to a common angle on the unit circle, we must use the inverse cosine function to solve for \theta, which gives us \theta = \cos^{-1}(0.6) \approx 0.927 \text{ radians}

Since 0.927 is greater than 0 and less than \pi/2 \approx 1.571, we know that \theta=0.927 lies in Quadrant I. Since the point (x,y)=(3,-4) is located in Quadrant IV, we must find the other angle on the unit circle with \cos(\theta) = 0.6

statement.p: Find the polar coordinates of a point with the Cartesian coordinates (x,y)=\left(-4\sqrt{2},4\sqrt{2}\right)

solution.p: Let's start by plotting the point (x,y)=(-4\sqrt{2},4\sqrt{2}) on a graph and using the Pythagorean theorem to find the corresponding radius of the point. We get that

Now that we know the radius, we can find the angle using any of the three trigonometric relationships. Keep in mind that there may be more than one solution when solving for \theta and we will need to consider the quadrant that our (x,y) point is in to decide which solution to use.
Using the sine function, we get that \sin(\theta) = \frac{y}{r} = \frac{4\sqrt{2}}{8}=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}

Since y=\sqrt{2}/2 corresponds to a common angle on the unit circle, we can find an exact angle. The two angles that have a sine value of \sqrt{2}\2 on the unit circle are \theta=\frac{\pi}{4} \hspace{.25in} \text{ and } \hspace{.25in} \theta=\frac{3\pi}{4}
Since the point (x,y)=(-4\sqrt{2},4\sqrt{2}) is located in Quadrant II, we can determine that \theta=3\pi/4. Thus, the polar coordinates are (r,\theta)=\left(8, \frac{3\pi}{4}\right)

subsection.title: Examples of Graphs in Polar Coordinates
subsection.p: Any equation written in Cartesian coordinates can be converted to one in polar coordinates and vice-versa. In practice, it makes sense to use the representation that is most natural for the application, or simpler to express. For example, the unit circle of radius 1 about the origin may be expressed in Cartesian coordinates using the equation x^2 + y^2 = 1. Since the points on the circle are precisely those points at distance r from the origin, in polar coordinates the equation may be written as r = 1.

Algebraically, we can see that this is correct by substituting x = r \cos(\theta) and y = r \sin(\theta) into the original equation to obtain x^2 + y^2 = 1 r^2 \cos^2(\theta) + r^2 \sin^2(\theta) = 1 r^2( \cos^2(\theta) + \sin^2(\theta) ) = 1 Using the trig identity \cos^2(\theta) + \sin^2(\theta) =1 , this becomes r^2 = 1 So, r = 1.
We now look at some special families of graphs in polar coordinates.

example.p: One interesting family of graphs in polar coordinates are the rose graphs . These are curves of the form r = a \cos (n \theta) or r = a \sin (n \theta), where n is a positive integer and a \gt 0 .

Another noteworthy graph is the Archimedean spiral . This curve has the equation r = \theta and is pictured below. The general class of spirals is given by the expression r = a + b\theta where a \gt 0 .

subsection.title: Area
subsection.p: First consider a circle of radius r . To find the area of a sector with angle \theta, we calculate the fraction of the area of the sector compared to the area of the circle. Thus, Area of Sector = \frac{\theta}{2\pi} (\pi r^2) = \frac{1}{2}r^2 \theta

assemblage.title: Area in polar coordinates
assemblage.p: For a curve r = f(\theta) where f(\theta) \ge 0 , the area under f(\theta) from \alpha to \beta is Area = \frac{1}{2} \int_{\alpha}^{\beta} f(\theta)^2 \ d\theta

subsection.title: Slope and Arc Length
subsection.p: We can think of a curve r = f(\theta) in terms of x and y using x = r \cos(\theta) and y = r\sin(\theta) . In this way, the curve may be seen as being parametrized by \theta . Thus, we may use the formulas for slope and arc length of parametric equations to obtain formulas for slope and arc length in polar coordinates.

assemblage.title: Slope in polar coordinates
assemblage.p: The slope of a curve r = f(\theta) is \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{(\frac{dy}{d\theta})}{(\frac{dx}{d\theta})}

assemblage.title: Arc length in polar coordinates
assemblage.p: The arc length of the curve r = f(\theta) where x = r \cos(\theta) and y = r\sin(\theta) is Arc Length = \int_\alpha^\beta \sqrt{(\frac{dx}{d \theta})^2 + (\frac{dy}{d \theta})^2 }
